title: What is the equilibrium constant for 2CO(g) + O2(g) <-> 2CO2(g)? - Quora

response.answer_text: The important concept to remember here is that equilibrium constant is a thermodynamic quantity that depends on temperature only. Change in Gibbs free energy of reaction and enthalpy are also important state function which help us calculate the equilibrium constant at different temperatures. Alternatively, one may try to find the equilibrium constant experimentally but that may not be easy to do. For such common gases, calculations are much easier. Now starting from the common equation as a function of composition [math]ΔG_r=ΔG°+RTln(Q)[/math] where superscript 0 indicates a standard quantity. at equilibrium Δ[math]G_r=0[/math] and [math]Q=K[/math]; the eqn becomes [math]ΔG°+RT_0 ln(K)=0[/math] Rearranging gives: [math]lnK=-ΔG°/RT_0 [/math]-->[math] K_0=exp(-ΔG°/RT_0) at T=T_0   ...(1)[/math] Now as we mentioned above, K is a function of temperature only. It is easy to show that [math]dlnK/dT=ΔH/(RT^2)[/math] [math]dlnK=ΔH/(RT^2)*dT[/math] integrating from [math]T_0[/math] to any temperature T and assuming the enthalpy change dependence on the temperature is weak. [math]ln(K/K_0)=-ΔH°/R *(1/T-1/T_0) [/math] [math]K/K_0=exp(-ΔH°/R *(1/T-1/T_0))[/math] [math]K=K_0*exp(-ΔH°/R *(1/T-1/T_0))[/math] substituting from equation (1) above [math]K=exp(-ΔG°/RT_0)*exp(-ΔH°/R *(1/T-1/T_0))[/math] [math]K=exp(-ΔG°/RT_0-ΔH°/R *(1/T-1/T_0))[/math] Now the question is how does one find [math]ΔG° and ΔH°[/math]; Also what if [math]ΔH°[/math] depends strongly on temperature? For finding these values we turn to thermodynamic tables which are very abundant everywhere. Any standard thermodynamics book or physical chemistry book will have a short table of standard formation quantities [math]ΔG_f°, ΔH_f°, Cp[/math] etc. If the compound is less common, one has to use longer tables such as: Thermochemical Data of Elements and Compounds: Michael Binnewies, E. Milkeor Thermochemical data of pure substances, Parts I & II: Ihsan Barin Regardless, at 25 °C (298 K) [math]ΔG°=2*-394.36-(2*-137.17+0)=-514.38 kJ/mol[/math] [math]ΔH°=2*-393.51-(2*-110.53+0)=-565.96 kJ/mol[/math] Finally: [math]K=exp(514380/(8.3144*298)+565960/8.3144 *(1/T-1/298))[/math] [math]K=1.448*10[/math]^(90)[math]*exp(68.1*10^3*(1/T-1/298))[/math] Note 1: as expected the combustion reaction is very favorable at most temperatures and the reaction is almost invariably irreversible. The reverse reaction becomes significant at T>3000 K or something similar. At such temperatures the bonds will probably preferably break up leading to a lot of gaseous atoms and ions mixtures. Note 2: This says nothing about the rate of the reaction. If the temperature is not high enough or there is no catalyst the reaction may take infinite time to reach equilibrium.Note 3: Note also that at such high temperatures, the assumption that [math]ΔH°[/math] depends weakly on temperature will fail and we will have to include the change in [math]ΔH(T)[/math] as well which is calculated from [math]C_p [/math]values also reported in those tables. ____________________________________________________________ For calculation of [math]K[/math] dependence at such high temperatures far away from [math]T_0[/math] one will need the [math]C_p[/math] temperature dependence from tables.
